raw_text:
England's defensive crisis grows
 
 England's defensive worries have deepened following the withdrawal of Tottenham's Ledley King from the squad to face Holland.
 
 Chelsea's John Terry and Wayne Bridge are also out, leaving coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a real problem for Wednesday's match at Villa Park. Injured Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell were both left out of the squad, and Matthew Upson has already pulled out. Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher are likely to be the makeshift partnership. Terry, the captain of Chelsea as they push for the Premiership title, would have been a certain starter in the absence of Campbell and Ferdinand. But now he has pulled out with a bruised knee and is likely to be replaced by Carragher, alongside Brown.
 
 Manchester United's Brown last played for England in the defeat by Australia at Upton Park in February 2003. The 25-year-old was only called into the squad on Sunday night as cover following the enforced withdrawal of Upson, who has a hamstring injury. And Brown now looks certain to add to his tally of seven senior appearances for England. King was forced to pull out after his groin injury was assessed by England's medical staff. Eriksson has still not decided whether to call up any further back-up, having already summoned Phil Neville after Bridge pulled out with a foot injury.
llama3.2:1b: England's defensive crisis deepens following Ledley King's withdrawal and other injuries, leaving coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a problem for Wednesday's match at Villa Park. Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell are also absent due to injury, and Jamie Carragher is likely to replace them in the makeshift partnership alongside Wes Brown. John Terry has pulled out with a bruised knee and will likely be replaced by Carragher, and Chelsea defender Matthew Upson has already withdrawn from the squad.

Wes Brown is likely to pair up with Jamie Carragher in a makeshift partnership, replacing John Terry who pulled out with a bruised knee.

Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher are likely to join as makeshift partners, potentially replacing injured Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell. England is looking to strengthen its backline ahead of the crucial match.

Chelsea's captain Terry is injured with no clear starter for Wednesday's match at Villa Park, leaving Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher as likely makeshift defenders. Manchester United’s Brown was last called up in 2003 for a defeat by Australia; he now looks certain to play after replacing Upson who has pulled out due to a hamstring injury. Eriksson hasn't decided on additional backups despite calling up Phil Neville following Wayne Bridge's withdrawal with a foot injury.

England's defensive crisis has been exacerbated by the withdrawal of Tottenham's Ledley King from the squad due to his groin injury, impacting their performance in the upcoming match against Holland. John Terry and Wayne Bridge are also out, leading to a significant problem at Wednesday's match at Villa Park. Injured players Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell have left the squad, while Matthew Upson has pulled out. Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher are likely the makeshift team. However, Terry is out due to his knee injury, which was forced after England's medical staff assessed him. Eriksson hasn't decided whether to bring in any more back-ups, with Phil Neville already summoned following Bridge's foot injury. Additionally, Manchester United's Brown has added a senior appearance since he last played for England against Australia in February 2003.
tinyllama:1.1b: England faces a significant defensive crisis following the withdrawal of Ledley King from their squad for their upcoming match against Holland. Chelsea's John Terry and Wayne Bridge are also missing, leaving coach Svon-Go-Ran Eriksson with a real problem for Wednesday's clash at Villa Park. Injured Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell have also been ruled out. Wes Brown is the likely makeshipt partnership in a defense ravaged by injuries and now set to be replaced by Manchester United midfielder Jamie Carragher, who has pulled out due to a knee injury. Brown's promotion to the starting lineup is a positive sign for England as they aim to claim a place at the World Cup finals. However, Eriksson's decision-making process may not always be clear-cut given the lack of available players.

With injuries to Chelsea captain John Terry and midfielders Martin Demichelis and Wayne Bridge, the Englishman has had to rely heavily on his makeshift partnership of Matthew Upson and Rio Ferdinand for much of the season. However, with Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell already injured, coach Eriksson may be forced to make changes to his lineup, with an uncertainty looming over his decision-making process. England's defensive crisis has deepened since the withdrawal of Ledley King from the squad, leaving coach Sven-Goran Eriksson with a real problem in his pursuit of Premiership success.

With limited options, coach Sven-Goran Eriksson is likely to field Wes Brown and Jamie Carragher as a makeshift defensive partnership. King withdrew due to a groin injury, and Eriksson has yet to decide on further reinforcements after already calling up Phil Neville.

Manchester United's Brown, last playing for England in 2003, was recently added to the squad as Terry's replacement due to Upson's hamstring injury. The team's defensive crisis is further exacerbated by the absence of Rio Ferdinand and Sol Campbell, with no reinforcements expected from Eriksson yet. Phil Neville has been called up after Bridge's foot injury forced his withdrawal.
